caption_original:
We’re excited about our first confirmed 2017 sighting of a basking shark in BC waters! This big guy was spotted in Caamano Sound and measures approximately 17 feet!
Basking sharks are an endangered species under the Species At Risk Act, and have rarely been seen in North American Pacific waters over the last 15 years.
Thank you to Archie Dundas of the GitGa’at Guardians for the video of this basking shark.
caption_cleaned: We’re excited about our first confirmed sighting of a basking shark in BC waters! This big guy was spotted in Caamano Sound and measures approximately feet! Basking sharks are an endangered species under the Species At Risk Act, and have rarely been seen in North American Pacific waters over the last years. Thank you to Archie Dundas of the GitGa’at Guardians for the video of this basking shark.

caption_original: Asian carps don’t belong in Canada. If you see one be sure to report it to the Invading Species Hotline at 1-800-563-7711. A dead, female Grass carp was found July 12 near Dunnville, ON and we are doing further testing. We want to thank the individual who spotted the fish and reported the find. http://ow.ly/CZfB30dH04D

We need your help once again!
Last fall, we heard great feedback on what you want to see in a revised Fisheries Act. 
This time around we want to hear from you on how to restore lost protections and incorporate modern safeguards through legislative, policy and program changes.

http://ow.ly/HOoW30dU5gJ

caption_original: Say hello to my little friend! Summer is here and our scientists are out on the water surveying Canada’s freshwater fish, like the muskellunge in Jeannettes Creek, Ontario. This environmental science, done by biologists like Julia Colm, is crucial to help protect Canada’s vast rivers and lakes, and the important marine species who call them home. http://ow.ly/PJEA30dJlxN

caption_original:
We’re deeply saddened by the loss of Campobello Whale Rescue expert Joe Howlett, who tragically lost his life while taking part in a rescue operation to disentangle a North Atlantic Right whale off the Eastern coast of New Brunswick. He was an experienced and valued member of the whale rescue community.
We are taking this incident very seriously and have paused all responses to entangled North Atlantic Right whales. While we are extremely concerned about the recent deaths and entanglements of these animals in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, it is imperative to review existing policies and practices regarding response to whale entanglements to ensure we proceed in the safest way possible for everyone involved.
During this time, we continue to take action towards the recovery, protection and conservation of endangered whales. For more information on the work DFO and partners are doing, and for status updates on the North Atlantic Right whale situation in the Gulf, view our website: http://ow.ly/XHhS30dL0XL

He was an eerienced and valued member of the whale rescue community. We are taking this incident very seriously and have paused all responses to entangled North Atlantic Right whales. While we are extremely concerned about the recent deaths and entanglements of these animals in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, it is imperative to review existing policies and practices regarding response to whale entanglements to ensure we proceed in the safest way possible for everyone involved. During this time, we continue to take action towards the recovery, protection and conservation of endangered whales. For more information on the work DFO and partners are doing, and for status updates on the North Atlantic Right whale situation in the Gulf, view our website:

caption_original: If you’re landing at the wharf in St. Philip’s after you’ve been out recreational cod fishing, go and introduce yourself to Sarah Quilty and Dylan Crichton. They’re two of the students DFO has hired for Citizen Cod 2017 in Newfoundland and Labrador. They’ll count your cod, measure them and pass that information along to our scientists for use in future stock assessments. Sarah and Dylan already say it’s a great summer job. They’re wearing bright orange shirts and they’re on the wharf from 6:30 until 2:30.

They’ll count your cod, measure them and pass that information along to our scientists for use in future stock assessments. Sarah and Dylan already say it’s a great summer job. They’re wearing bright orange shirts and they’re on the wharf from :30 until :30.

caption_original: Make sure you have your chart before heading out on the water. From shallow to deep waters, the Canadian Hydrographic Service creates detailed nautical charts using both light and sound emission technology. It’s this combination that saves lives, property and the environment by ensuring safe navigation in all of Canada’s waterways. Find your chart here: http://ow.ly/F5Jq30dWbAj

caption_original:
We’re LIVE from 2250 meters deep off the coast of Vancouver Island, getting first ever footage of two previously unexplored underwater mountains!
Our scientists are standing by to answer your questions about science at sea. Their research will help inform conservation efforts of the Offshore Pacific Area of Interest where these seamounts are located. 
Tune in! http://ow.ly/V6Ku30dOPWR

Our scientists are standing by to answer your questions about science at sea. Their research will help inform conservation efforts of the Offshore Pacific Area of Interest where these seamounts are located. Tune in!

caption_original: Canadian researchers discovered a new species of carnivious sponge, Cladorhiza kenchingtonae. It is two metres long with Velcro-like surface and feeds on zooplankton. The sponge is named after the lead DFO scientist who discovered it, Ellen Kenchington. http://ow.ly/PKOt30dWd3z
caption_cleaned: Canadian researchers discovered a new species of carnivious sponge, Cladorhiza kenchingtonae. It is two metres long with Velcro-like surface and feeds on zooplankton. The sponge is named after the lead DFO scientist who discovered it, Ellen Kenchington.

caption_original: Newfoundland and Labrador has 12 species of skates in its waters. Twelve!! Bigelow’s Skate is one of the smallest and Richardson’s Skate is one of the largest - at almost 175 cm long. If you see a skate anywhere, take a photo. If you find an egg case or Mermaid’s Purse, please save it. In both cases, contact Carolyn.Miri@dfo-mpo.gc.ca. http://ow.ly/JcVb30dUAz1

If you see a skate anywhere, take a photo. If you find an egg case or Mermaid’s Purse, please save it. In both cases, contact Carolyn.Miri-mpo.gc.ca. 1

caption_original: The Nunatsiavut Government, DFO in Newfoundland & Labrador and the Atlantic Salmon Federation are tagging salmon in Lake Melville, this summer. We want to know more about Atlantic salmon and their migration patterns. If you find these scientific tags, please return them immediately to DFO in Happy Valley - Goose Bay or your local Fishery Officer. There’s a small monetary reward for all returned tags. http://ow.ly/198X30dE0np

caption_original:
The basking shark might be the rudest dinner guest in Canadian waters. In the summer, they swim into our Atlantic waters with their big mouth WIDE open to filter as much plankton as possible. As it gets colder, they take off and leave! 
We don’t even know where they’re going! That’s why we’re using a dart tagging program to better understand their movements and populations, so we can better track these big gluttons.
Happy Shark Week, Canada! 
http://ow.ly/LqKC30dRwGX
caption_cleaned: The basking shark might be the rudest dinner guest in Canadian waters. In the summer, they swim into our Atlantic waters with their big mouth WIDE open to filter as much plankton as possible. As it gets colder, they take off and leave! We don’t even know where they’re going! That’s why we’re using a dart tagging program to better understand their movements and populations, so we can better track these big gluttons. Happy Shark Week, Canada!

caption_original:
Take a virtual tour of our Maurice Lamontagne Institute, Fisheries and Oceans Canada’s only francophone research center. Everything they do is meant to advance science in fresh and marine waters. 
Enjoyed our video and want to learn more by visiting us in person in Mont-Joli, Quebec? You’re in luck! This summer, as part of its 30th anniversary, the Institute is open to the public Monday to Friday, from 9 am to 4 pm. Book your spot now for one of our free guided tours by calling 418-775-0500.

caption_original: Ever wonder why there are so many red animals in the deep sea? Red is the first colour filtered out by light so it cannot reach past certain ocean depths. Red coloured deep sea creatures appear black which helps camouflage them against predators. We’re exploring deep sea mountains in the Pacific Ocean as we speak, so tune in to our live dive and see if you can spot some red animals like the rockfish. http://ow.ly/KjGN30dXXwY
caption_cleaned: Ever wonder why there are so many red animals in the deep sea? Red is the first colour filtered out by light so it cannot reach past certain ocean depths. Red coloured deep sea creatures appear black which helps camouflage them against predators. We’re eloring deep sea mountains in the Pacific Ocean as we speak, so tune in to our live dive and see if you can spot some red animals like the rockfish.

caption_original:
Tell us about your shark sightings!
We’re passionate about sharks in Newfoundland and Labrador waters. If you see a shark (even dead on a shore or beach), please put on your “citizen scientist” hat and help our shark researchers. When you’re walking on the beach or enjoying a day on the water and you see a shark, record the date, location, estimated length and possible species. Take photos – if you can - of its full body length and close-ups of its largest top fin, head or teeth (to confirm species), and underbelly (to confirm sex) to see if 2 male “claspers” or finger-like projections are there. Send all that information to Carolyn.Miri@dfo-mpo.gc.ca
caption_cleaned: Tell us about your shark sightings! We’re passionate about sharks in Newfoundland and Labrador waters. If you see a shark (even dead on a shore or beach), please put on your “citizen scientist” hat and help our shark researchers. When you’re walking on the beach or enjoying a day on the water and you see a shark, record the date, location, estimated length and possible species. Take photos – if you can - of its full body length and close-ups of its largest top fin, head or teeth (to confirm species), and underbelly (to confirm se to see if male “claspers” or finger-like projections are there. Send all that information to Carolyn.Miri-mpo.gc.ca

caption_original:
We’re working with members of Indigenous organizations and watershed associations in Miramichi New Brunswick to learn how we can better protect the Brook Floater, an at risk freshwater mussel. We’re training our partners on how to identify the mussels, monitor their health, gather data, and more so we can know more about the species, what it needs, its distribution and how to maintain healthy populations and freshwater systems.

Thank you to the New Brunswick Museum - Musée du Nouveau-Brunswick, Miramichi River Environmental Assessment committee and Anqotum Resource Management for your collaboration!

We’re training our partners on how to identify the mussels, monitor their health, gather data, and more so we can know more about the species, what it needs, its distribution and how to maintain healthy populations and freshwater systems. Thank you to the New Brunswick Museum - Musée du Nouveau-Brunswick, Miramichi River Environmental Assessment committee and Anqotum Resource Management for your collaboration!

caption_original: Buyer Beware! Be careful when purchasing illegal seafood online. It by-passes food safety controls that protect Canadians from the health risks associated with consuming contaminated food. Both sellers and buyers of illegal seafood could be subject to fines. Plus it can contribute to poaching of endangered species like Northern Abalone. Check out more information on illegal sale of seafood here: http://ow.ly/Fe3830e2Js4

caption_original:
The first weeks of a Beluga whale's life are a transitional period during which the mother–calf bond is established. Since the calf's cries are still very faint, the mother may easily lose her baby if they wander too far from one another. This is why it’s important not to disturb these animals.
In the presence of Beluga whales, keep your distance. #Beluga400m
For more information about best practices for navigation around Beluga whales: http://ow.ly/UK5q30dMQFg  
And about the Regulations in the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park: http://ow.ly/il8g30dMQJM

Since the calf's cries are still very faint, the mother may easily lose her baby if they wander too far from one another. This is why it’s important not to disturb these animals. In the presence of Beluga whales, keep your distance. For more information about best practices for navigation around Beluga whales: And about the Regulations in the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park:

caption_original:
Report your capelin sightings to ecapelin.ca! 
In Newfoundland and Labrador when the capelin starts to roll, everyone gets excited, especially our scientists. Capelin is a key source of food in our ecosystem and we need to know as much as we can. We need you to be citizen scientists and report sightings to ecapelin.ca. The website, created in collaboration with WWF Canada, is quick and easy to use http://ow.ly/rkTE30dwbdn

The website, created in collaboration with WWF Canada, is quick and easy to use

If you see a beluga whale: keep your distance, slow down, and move at least 400 metres away #Beluga400m
More best practices for navigation around beluga whales can be found here: http://ow.ly/UK5q30dMQFg

caption_original: Oysters are self-cleaning animals. Their ability to rid themselves of contaminants when placed in clean waters allows for a special kind of fishery in Prince Edward Island, called the Oyster Relay. Watch these oyster harvesters take part in a fishery that’s been around for as long as they can remember.

caption_original: Did you know that Nunavik, Quebec, is home to the only known population of harbor seals living exclusively in freshwater in the world? The subspecies of the Lacs des Loups Marins harbour seal have been isolated from their original marine habitat for over 3,000 years. Find out more about this endangered mammal recently protected by the Species at Risk Act: http://ow.ly/bpMo30dvJM5

caption_original: Experts from Fisheries and Oceans Canada and their partners describe for the first time the effects of a "red tide". The neurotoxins contained in the algae that caused the red tide in the St. Lawrence Estuary in 2008 resulted in the death of a large number of fish, birds and marine mammals. The findings of the team of experts provide a better understanding of the causes and effects of this mass mortality and consider actions to be taken to protect ecosystems. Want to know more? http://bit.ly/2tgpkIs

The findings of the team of eerts provide a better understanding of the causes and effects of this mass mortality and consider actions to be taken to protect ecosystems. Want to know more?

caption_original: This summer, enjoy the natural beauty Canada’s tides have to offer! Get out on the water, go for a walk on the beach, harvest shellfish and build sand castles. But before you do, be sure to check the 2017 Canadian Tide and Current http://ow.ly/ssF330dOZSI

caption_original: Calling all salmon anglers in Newfoundland and Labrador! Please be sure you fill out your salmon angling log during the 2017-2018 season. It’s the primary source of catch-and-effort information used by our scientists to assess the status of our salmon stocks. Any, and all, information helps. And, when you participate, you’ll be entered to win some great prizes from the Salmonid Association of Eastern Newfoundland (SAEN) in co-operation with DFO and the province. http://ow.ly/zZHH30doSsa
caption_cleaned: Calling all salmon anglers in Newfoundland and Labrador! Please be sure you fill out your salmon angling log during the -2018 season. It’s the primary source of catch-and-effort information used by our scientists to assess the status of our salmon stocks. Any, and all, information helps. And, when you participate, you’ll be entered to win some great prizes from the Salmonid Association of Eastern Newfoundland (SAEN) in co-operation with DFO and the province.

caption_original: Commercial fishers in Quebec: Fisheries and Oceans Canada reminds you that the transition period between the qualification processes for commercial licenses has been extended to December 31, 2018. http://ow.ly/Z1yo30dvWkz
